http://www.28msec.com/modules/assertion.doc: This module provides a set of assertion methods useful for writing tests.

equals-general.doc: Asserts that two objects are equal (by general comarison). If they are not, an error containing the diff is thrown.

equals-deep.doc: Asserts that two objects are deep-equal. If they are not, an error containing the diff is thrown.

equals-value.doc: Asserts that two objects are equal (by value comarison). If they are not, an error containing the diff is thrown.

http://www.28msec.com/modules/error.doc: Applications written with Sausalito use this default error module if an error happens inside a Sausalito project. An error can occur during the run time of a Sausalito project on one of the following cases: If the XQuery code raises a dynamic error that is not caught in a try-catch block. If the giv...

handle.doc: This is the default function that is called if an error happens. The default can be overridden by adding an error.xq library module into the Sausalito project. This module needs to declare a function with the same signature as the err:handle function in this module. The value returned by this functi...

http-status.doc: Convert the given error QName into an HTTP status code.

http://www.28msec.com/modules/http/cooki.doc: The Sausalito Cookie module provides function to manipulate HTTP-Cookies.

create-session.doc: Creates a client-side cookie named "_session", containing the $sessionData node value together with its signature. The signature is generated with the server's private key.

Creates a client-side cookie named "_session", containing the $sessionData node value together with its signature. The signature is generated with the server's private key. The cookie is also set to expire on the date specified by $expires .

Creates a client-side cookie named "_session", containing the $sessionData node value together with its signature. The signature is generated with the server's private key. The cookie is also set to expire on the date specified by $expires . The cookie is only valid for the specified path.

session-data.doc: Reads the "_session" cookie in the request and verifies if the signature matches the ad-hoc computed signature of the content of the session. If the verification is successful, the function returns the session data. Otherwise, an error is raised.

delete-session.doc: Delete the "_session" cookie from the client. The next user request will not receive a valid session cookie anymore
Delete the "_session" cookie from the client. The next user request will not receive a valid session cookie anymore

validate-session.doc: Reads the "_session" cookie in the request and verifies if the signature matches the ad-hoc computed signature of the content of the session. The signature is generated with a server private key. If no cookie named "_session" exists, this function returns false.

set.doc: Adds a Set-Cookie header to the response. This function is equivalent to cookie:set($cookie, fn:true()) .

Adds a Set-Cookie header to the response. The cookie parameter needs to adhere to the cookie schema. For example, <cookie:cookie name="xs:string" expires="xs:datetime" domain="xs:string" path="xs:string" secure="xs:boolean">value</cookie:cookie> . If the cookie parameter is not valid according to th...

get.doc: Returns the cookie in the request having the given name or the empty sequence if no such cookie exists. The cookie format returned is: <cookie:cookie name="..">...</cookie:cookie> . The content of the cookie element is the value of the cookie.

Returns the cookies in the request having the given name. If no name is given, it returns all available cookies. If no cookie value decoding is wanted, the user must specify a second argument that evaluates to fn:false().

create-session-path.doc: Computes the default path for session cookies if no path is passed by the user. It takes the path of the request URL, up to, but not including, the right-most /. Set http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2109.txt

http://www.28msec.com/modules/http/reque.doc: The Sausalito request module provides functions for accessing information contained in the current HTTP request. For example, the parameter-names function can be used to retrieve all the names of the parameters contained in a request.

method-delete.doc: Returns true if the HTTP method of this request is DELETE.

text-part.doc: Returns the value of a part as string A part is identified by a reference that is the value of a src attribute returned by the request:parts function. The value of the text part is interpreted using the encoding/charset given in the headers of the part. If no encoding is given, the default US-ASCII ...
Returns the value of a part as string interpreting it with the given encoding. A part is identified by a reference that is the value of a src attribute returned by the request:parts function.

server-port.doc: Returns the sever port to which the client making the current request is connected.

header-names.doc: Returns the names of all the HTTP headers in this request. Header fields are colon-separated name-value pairs, terminated by a carriage return (CR) and line feed (LF) character sequence. The names and values of each header are allowed to consist of US-ASCII characters only. The names of the headers ...

method-get.doc: Returns true if the HTTP method of this request is GET.

remote-addr.doc: Returns the IP address of the client to which this request is connected.

method.doc: Returns the name of the HTTP method used to make this request.

method-put.doc: Returns true if the HTTP method of this request is PUT.

content-length.doc: Returns the length of the content in bytes. The value returned corresponds to the value of the HTTP content-length header. The function returns an empty sequence if this header does not exist in the request or its value could not be converted to item of type xs:integer .

parameter-names.doc: Returns the names of the parameters contained in the current request. Parameters are name-value pairs contained in the query string of the URL used to make this request. As defined in RFC 1738, the query string of a URL starts with a "?" character and ends with the character (if any). Additionally, ...

Returns the names of the parameters contained in the current request. This function is similar to the request:parameter-names#0 function. However, the names are treated (after precent-decoding) using the given encoding supplied as parameter. For example, parameters might be encoded using the ISO-885...

method-post.doc: Returns true if the HTTP method of this request is POST.

method-head.doc: Returns true if the HTTP method of this request is HEAD.

content-type.doc: Returns the content-type of the data sent with this request. Note that the content-type is only set for PUT and POST requests.

parameter-values.doc: Returns a sequence of parameter values for the given parameter name which are contained in the URL's query string or the body of a POST or PUT request. Parameters are name-value pairs contained in the query string of the URL used to make this request. As defined in RFC 1738, the query string of a UR...

Returns a sequence of parameter values for the given parameter name which are contained in the URL's query string or the body of a POST or PUT request. This function is similar to the request:parameter-values#1 function. However, instead of returning the empty-sequence as a default value it returns ...

Returns a sequence of parameter values for the given parameter name which are contained in the URL's query string or the body of a POST or PUT request. This function is similar to the request:parameter-values#2 function. However, the names and values are treated (after precent-decoding) using the gi...

path.doc: Return the path component of the request URI. The path starts after the host and ends before the query string starts.

method-options.doc: Returns true if the HTTP method of this request is OPTION.

user-agent.doc: Returns the user agent that made to perform the current request. This function returns the value of the User-Agent header contained in the current request.

binary-content.doc: Returns the content of the request as base64Binary.

header-value.doc: Returns the value of the HTTP header with the given name. Header fields are colon-separated name-value pairs, terminated by a carriage return (CR) and line feed (LF) character sequence. The names and values of each header are allowed to consist of US-ASCII characters only. Please note that header na...

text-content.doc: Returns the content of the request as string. The function returns the content of the request only if the content-type refers to a type that can be treated as text (e.g. text/* or application/xml). The function raises an error if the content cannot be treated as text. The text content is interpreted...

Returns the content of the request as string interpreting it with the given encoding. The function returns the content of the request only if the content-type refers to a type that can be treated as text (e.g. text/* or application/xml). The function raises an error if the content cannot be treated ...

query-string.doc: Returns the query string that was used to make this request. The query string contains the part of the request URL that starts with the '?' character to the end or the starting of the fragment (i.e. the '#' character).

remote-port.doc: Returns the port of the client to which this request is connected.

server-name.doc: Returns the server name of the server running the application. The web server's hostname or IP address.

uri.doc: Returns the URI that was used to make this request. The value returned contains the part of the URL starting from the path to the end or the starting of the fragment (i.e. the '#' character).

binary-part.doc: Returns the value of a part as base64Binary. A part is identified by a reference that is the value of a src attribute returned by the request:parts function.

parts.doc: Returns the metadata of all parts contained in a multipart request. The data is returned as an element with name request:mulitpart as shown in the following example. <multipart xmlns="http://www.28msec.com/modules/http/request" media-type="multipart/...; boundary=..."> <header name="Content-Disposit...

http://www.28msec.com/modules/http/respo.doc: The Sausalito response module can be used to modify the HTTP response that will be send as a result of this request. For example, the set-content-type function can be used to set the Content-Type header and determine the encoding of data in the response.

set-redirect.doc: This function sets the HTTP 302 redirect status code in the response. As a result, a redirect to the URL given as parameter will be made.

code-for-status.doc: Convert between the HTTP status code as QName and the integer value of that status code.

serializer-defaults-text.doc: Returns an element that can be used to specify the settings of serialization parameters for the text serialization method. The only default used is encoding: UTF-8 For example, this default is used when setting the content-type to some text content-type (e.g. text/plain).

content-type-binary.doc: Test if a given content-type is a binary content-type. A content-type is considered to be binary if it's not a text content-type.

serializer-defaults-xhtml.doc: Returns an element that can be used to specify the settings of serialization parameters for the XHTML serialization method. The defaults are encoding: UTF-8 indent: yes omit-xml-declaration: yes version: 1.0 doctype-system: http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd doctype-public: -//W...

set-serialization-parameters.doc: Set the serialization parameters used for serializing the result of the request. The following example shows how to set several options for the HTML serialization method. Specifically, it sets the HTML method to HTML 4.01, set the doctype-system and doctype-public makes sure that the output is inden...

content-type-xhtml.doc: Test if a given content-type is a XHTML content-type, i.e. the content-type is the string "application/xhtml+xml".

content-type-html.doc: Test if a given content-type is a HTML content-type, i.e. the content-type is the string "text/html".

serializer-defaults-xml.doc: Returns an element that can be used to specify the settings of serialization parameters for the XML serialization method. The defaults are encoding: UTF-8 indent: yes omit-xml-declaration: yes version: 1.0 For example, those defaults are used when setting the content-type to some XML content-type (e...

set-status-code.doc: Sets the status code of the HTTP response to the integer given as parameter. For example, resp:set-status(204) will result in "HTTP/1.1 204 No Content".

content-type-json.doc: Test if a given content-type is a JSON content-type, i.e. the content-type is the string "application/json".

set-content-type.doc: Sets the Content-Type header for the response. For example, resp:set-content-type("text/plain") will cause the header Content-Type: text/plain to be added for the response. In addtion to setting the Content-Type header, the function also sets the serialization parameters to the default values for se...

Sets the Content-Type header for the response. For example, resp:set-content-type("text/plain") will cause the header Content-Type: text/plain to be added for the response. In addition to the content-type, the function also allows to specify the serialization method and parameters that will be used ...

serializer-defaults-html.doc: Returns an element that can be used to specify the settings of serialization parameters for the HTML serialization method. The defaults are encoding: UTF-8 indent: yes version: 4.01 doctype-system: http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd doctype-public: -//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN include-co...

set-header.doc: Set a HTTP header in the response. If a header with the same name was already set, the value is overwritten and the function returns the old value. As defined in the HTTP specification, multiple headers with the same name can be combined into one header whose value is a comma-separated list of the v...

message-for-status.doc: Convert between the HTTP status code as QName and the name/message of that status code.

valid-status.doc: Test whether the given QName refers to a valid HTTP status code.

set-decode-binary.doc: If this function is invoked with true, the result of the request will not be serialized. Instead, the result will be the binary values of any item that is of type xs:base64Binary. The values of all other items will not be part of the result. Please note that all serialization parameters which have b...

set-status.doc: Sets the status code of the HTTP response to the QName given as parameter. For example, resp:set-status($http:no-content) will result in "HTTP/1.1 204 No Content".

set-encoding.doc: The function sets the output encoding that will be used for the payload of the response. For example, resp:set-encoding("ISO-8859-1") will cause the content in the response to be encoded using ISO-8859-1. Please note that the encoding only applies to textual data. It is not used if the function set-...

serialization-parameters.doc: Returns the serialization parameters that are currently active, i.e. the ones that will be used to serialize the result of this request. This will either be the default, the defaults set when calling resp:set-content-type(), or the ones set by resp:set-serialization-parameters().

content-type-xml.doc: Test if a given content-type is a XML content-type A XML content-type is a content-type that is "application/xml" or ends : with the string "+xml".

content-type-text.doc: Test if a given content-type is a text content-type. A text content-type starts with "text/" or contains either of the strings "xml" or "json".

decode-binary.doc: Returns the boolean indiciating whether base64Binaries returned by this request will be decoded. The default if not modified using resp:set-decode-binary is false.

set-header-impl.doc: Set a HTTP header in the response.

serializer-defaults-jsoniq.doc: Returns an element that can be used to specify the settings of serialization parameters for the JSONiq serialization method. The defaults are encoding: UTF-8 indent: yes omit-xml-declaration: yes version: 1.0 jsoniq-extensions: yes jsoniq-xdm-node-output-method: xml jsoniq-multiple-items: appended F...

http://www.28msec.com/modules/http/util/.doc: This module contains a collection of convenience functions to help developers work with HTTP caching options.

no-cache.doc: Forces a client not to cache the response by setting the appropriate HTTP headers. In detail, the following HTTP headers will be set in the response: Cache-Control: no-cache Pragma: no-cache Expires: 0

http://www.28msec.com/modules/http/util/.doc: This module provides utility functions to help with diagnostic analysis / debugging of RESTful Apps or webapps.

serialize-request-as-txt.doc: Returns a sequence of xs:string listing all request characteristics. This function is helpful for debugging purposes. It can be used to output request information as plan text.

serialize-request-as-html.doc: Returns a sequence of html elements listing all request characteristics. This function is helpful for debugging purposes. It can be used to output request information within an HTML page.

http://www.28msec.com/modules/http/util/.doc: This module provides utility functions to help dealing with the content of multipart requests. In their implementation, all the functions use the multipart related functions of the request module (e.g. parts() or text-part()).

binary-file.doc: Returns the contents of the part/file in the multipart requests with the given filename as xs:base64Binary. Please note that the file is identified by the filename (and not the name of the part) that is contained in the Content-Disposition header of the part.

content-length.doc: Returns the content length of the parts/files in the multipart requests with the given part name as xs:integer.

names.doc: Returns the names of all the parts contained in the multipart content of the given request.

text-file.doc: Returns the contents of the part/file in the multipart requests with the given filename as a string. It is assumed that the character set of the file is UTF-8. Please note that the file is identified by the filename (and not the name of the part) that is contained in the Content-Disposition header o...

content-type.doc: Returns the content type of the parts/files in the multipart requests with the given part name as xs:string.

part.doc: Returns the req:part element among all the parts contained in the multipart requests with the given name.

filename.doc: Returns the filenames of the parts/files in the multipart requests with the given part name as xs:string.

binary-content.doc: Returns the contents of the parts/files in the multipart requests with the given part name as xs:base64Binary.

text-content.doc: Returns the contents of the parts/files in the multipart requests with the given part name as a string. It is assumed that the character set of the file is UTF-8.

filenames.doc: Returns the filenames of all the parts contained in the multipart content of the given request.

http://www.28msec.com/modules/lock.doc: Sausalito provides a an application level locking mechanism that can be used e.g. to ensure exclusive access to data. As the store ensures atomicity of of single document updates, atomic updates to multiple documents are implemented using this mechanism. Locks can be acquired and re-acquired at any ...

try-acquire.doc: Tries to acquire a lock. This operation is non-blocking if the lock cannot be acquired immediately. To check and modify the stock of a product wihtout interference from concurrent requests a lock could be used like this: if (lock:try-acquire("stock-update")) then if (stock:check($product-id)) then {...

http://www.28msec.com/modules/mongodb.doc: This module provides a driver to access a MongoDB database - similar to drivers for other high-level languages like e.g. PyMongo . Here is a simple example of how we can raise the salary of each developer by 10%. Starting with an employees collection in MongoDB that contains { "name" : "Peter", "rol...

count.doc: Counts the number of documents in the given collection.

remove.doc: Performs a remove operation on the given collection. The operation will be checked and an error is raised if one of them fails.

Performs a remove operation on the given collection. safe: If to true, the operation will wait for a response from the database and an error is raised if the operation fails. Otherwise, the operation will not wait for a response. just-one: true if the operation should stop after a single match has b...

is-connected.doc: Checks if the given identifiers is valid and the corresponding connection is open.

update.doc: Performs an update command on the given collection. The operation will be checked and an error is raised if one of them fails. Also, this function only modifies one document matching the query and does not do any upserts.

Performs an update operation on the given collection. safe: If to true, the operation will wait for a response from the database and an error is raised if the operation fails. Otherwise, the operation will not wait for a response. multi: indicates if all documents matching criteria should be updated...

connect.doc: Connect to a MongoDB database. The options object can contain the following values: host (string; mandatory) port (integer; default: 27017) db (string; mandatory) user (string) pass (string)

save.doc: Save a sequence of documents in the given collection. If a document to be save already has an "_id" field, then an upsert operation is performed an any existing document with that id will be overwritten. Otherwise, an insert operation is performed and the "_id" generated for each document will be re...

Save a sequence of documents in the given collection. If a document to be saved already has an "_id" field, then an upsert operation is performed and any existing document with that id will be overwritten. Otherwise, an insert operation is performed If the manipulate option is set to true, an "_id" ...

find.doc: Returns all objects of the given collection.
Performs a query operation on the given collection and returns all matches.
Performs a query operation on the given collection and returns all matches.

Performs a query operation on the given collection and returns all matches. Available options: to-return: the maximum number of objects to return (0 = unlimited) to-skip: start with the n-th object batch-size: the number of objects to return in one batch slave-ok: allow this query to be run against ...

collection-names.doc: Get a list of all the collection names in this database.

http://www.28msec.com/modules/sequence.doc: The sequence module allows you to generate consecutive application-unique xs:integer ids. This is required e.g. in accounting applications as some legislations require consecutive invoice numbers.

id.doc: Returns a unique (sequentially incremented) id for the uri specified as parameter. Here the function is used to create consecutive invoice numbers: if (order:fulfilled($order-id)) then { variable $invoice-id := seq:id("invoice"); invoice:create($invoice-id, $order-id); } else ...

acquire-lock.doc: Tries to acquire a lock that ensures consistent modifications of the counter for the uri specified as parameter. Throws seq:failed if the lock cannnot be acquired.

reset.doc: Resets the unique (sequentially incremented) id generation for the uri specified as parameter.

value.doc: Returns the id for the uri specified as parameter without incrementing it.

http://www.28msec.com/modules/sleep.doc: This module provides a function to put the currently executing request to sleep.

millis.doc: Puts the currently executing request to sleep. This function is mainly useful in development e.g. to simulate the effects of long-running tasks wrt. the concurrent execution of requests. Here the function is used to simulate a request that runs for 1 second declare $acquired := lock:try-acquire("my-...

http://www.28msec.com/modules/store.doc: This modules provides functions that allow to have more control over the data store. For example, the flush() function may be used to synchronously flush all pending modifications and make them available to other requests.

flush-if.doc: Same functionality as the flush function, but it only flushes conditionally. A typical use of this function to bulkload a large number of nodes could look as follows: for $i at $y in 1 to 8193 return { store:flush-if($y mod 100 eq 0); db:insert-nodes(xs:QName("foo:mycollection"), {$i} ); }

flush.doc: The flush function flushes all pending modifications to persistent storage such that they are immediately available to other requests. This function is particularly useful if a huge number of modifications (i.e. updates to nodes or collections) are made during one request or during the initial bulkl...

clear.doc: The clear function completely clears Sausalito's buffer. It is an error if the currently executing request references an item in the buffer as the buffer cannot be completely cleared in that case. This function is mainly useful in development e.g. to verify that the data in the presistent storage is...

clear-if.doc: Same functionality as the clear function, but it only clears conditionally.

list-clients.doc: Retrieve the clients that the list's subscribers have been tagged as being used based on user agents seen. Made possible by user-agent-string.info double penetration the percent of desktop clients in use array clients a record containing the 'client', an 'icon' image url, the 'percent' using the cli...

campaign-unschedule.doc: Unschedule a campaign that is scheduled to be sent in the future.

campaign-share-report.doc: Get the URL to a customized VIP Report for the specified campaign and optionally send an email to someone with links to it. Note subsequent calls will overwrite anything already set for the same campign (eg, the password).

list-merge-var-del.doc: Delete a merge tag from a given list and all its members. Seriously - the data is removed from all members as well! Note that on large lists this method may seem a bit slower than calls you typically make.

folder-add.doc: Add a new folder to file campaigns or autoresponders in.

apikeys.doc: Retrieve a list of all MailChimp API Keys for this User.

campaign-geo-opens.doc: Retrieve the countries and number of opens tracked for each. Email address are not returned.

campaign-email-stats-AIM-all.doc: Given a campaign and correct paging limits, return the entire click and open history with timestamps, ordered by time, for every user a campaign was delivered to.

list-static-segment-del.doc: Delete a static segment. Note that this will, of course, remove any member affiliations with the segment.

list-abuse-reports.doc: Get all email addresses that complained about a given campaign.

list-batch-subscribe.doc: Subscribe a batch of email addresses to a list at once. If you are using a serialized version of the API, we strongly suggest that you only run this method as a POST request, and not a GET request. Maximum batch sizes vary based on the amount of data in each record, though you should cap them at 5k ...

list-static-segment-members-del.doc: Remove list members from a static segment. It is suggested that you limit batch size to no more than 10,000 addresses per call. Email addresses must exist on the list in order to be removed - this will not unsubscribe them from the list!.

list-interest-groupings.doc: Get the list of interest groupings for a given list, including the label, form information, and included groups for each.

get-account-details.doc: Retrieve lots of account information including payments made, plan info, some account stats, installed modules, contact info, and more.

ecomm-order-add.doc: Import Ecommerce Order Information to be used for Segmentation.

campaign-create.doc: Create a new draft campaign to send. You can not have more than 32,000 campaigns in your account.

list-static-segments.doc: Retrieve all of the Static Segments for a list.

campaign-bounce-message.doc: Retrieve the most recent full bounce message for a specific email address on the given campaign. Messages over 30 days old are subject to being removed.

campaign-hard-bounces.doc: DEPRECATED Get all email addresses with Hard Bounces for a given campaign the email address that bounced.

template-update.doc: Replace the content of a user template, NOT campaign content.

campaign-template-content.doc: Get the HTML template content sections for a campaign. Note that this will return very jagged, non-standard results based on the template a campaign is using. You only want to use this if you want to allow editing template sections in your applicaton.

list-member-activity.doc: Get the most recent 100 activities for particular list members (open, click, bounce, unsub, abuse, sent to).

campaign-ecomm-order-add.doc: Attach Ecommerce Order Information to a Campaign.

campaign-resume.doc: Resume sending an AutoResponder or RSS campaign.

campaign-content.doc: Get the content (both html and text) for a campaign either as it would appear in the campaign archive or as the raw, original content.

list-update-member.doc: Edit the email address, merge fields, and interest groups for a list member. If you are doing a batch update on lots of users, consider using #list-batch-subscribe() with the update_existing and possible replace_interests parameter.

campaign-schedule.doc: Schedule a campaign to be sent in the future.

folder-del.doc: Delete a campaign or autoresponder folder. Note that this will simply make campaigns in the folder appear unfiled, they are not removed.

list-interest-group-update.doc: Change the name of an Interest Group.

campaign-bounce-messages.doc: Retrieve the full bounce messages for the given campaign. Note that this can return very large amounts of data depending on how large the campaign was and how much cruft the bounce provider returned.

list-locations.doc: Retrieve the locations (countries) that the list's subscribers have been tagged to based on geocoding their IP address.

campaign-abuse-reports.doc: Get all email addresses that complained about a given campaign.

list-merge-vars.doc: Get the list of merge tags for a given list, including their name, tag, and required setting.

folders.doc: List all the folders for a user account.

campaign-analytics.doc: Retrieve the Google Analytics data we've collected for this campaign. Note, requires Google Analytics Add-on to be installed and configured.

list-activity.doc: Access up to the previous 180 days of daily detailed aggregated activity stats for a given list.

list-growth-history.doc: Access the Growth History by Month for a given list.

campaign-unsubscribes.doc: Get all unsubscribed email addresses for a given campaign.

list-webhook-add.doc: Add a new Webhook URL for the given list.

campaigns.doc: Get the list of campaigns and their details matching the specified filters.

ecomm-order-del.doc: Delete Ecommerce Order Information used for segmentation. This will generally be used by ecommerce package plugins that we provide or by 3rd part system developers.

template-add.doc: Create a new user template, NOT campaign content. These templates can then be applied while creating campaigns.

list-members.doc: Get all of the list members for a list that are of a particular status.

campaign-click-detail-AIM.doc: Return the list of email addresses that clicked on a given url, and how many times they clicked.

list-merge-var-update.doc: Update most parameters for a merge tag on a given list. You cannot currently change the merge type.

campaign-geo-opens-for-country.doc: Retrieve the regions and number of opens tracked for a certain country. Email address are not returned.

apikey-add.doc: Add an API Key to your account. We will generate a new key for you and return it.

campaign-not-opened-AIM.doc: Retrieve the list of email addresses that did not open a given campaign string email Email address that opened the campaign.

campaign-email-domain-performance.doc: Get the top 5 performing email domains for this campaign. Users want more than 5 should use campaign campaign-email-stats-AIM() or campaign-email-stats-AIM-all() and generate any additional stats they require.

campaign-ecomm-orders.doc: Retrieve the Ecommerce Orders tracked by campaign-ecomm-order-add() .

list-interest-group-add.doc: Add a single Interest Group - if interest groups for the List are not yet enabled, adding the first group will automatically turn them on.

campaign-eep-url-stats.doc: Retrieve the tracked eepurl mentions on Twitter.

list-unsubscribe.doc: Unsubscribe the given email address from the list.

generate-text.doc: Have HTML content auto-converted to a text-only format. You can send: plain HTML, an array of Template content, an existing Campaign Id, or an existing Template Id. Note that this will not save anything to or update any of your lists, campaigns, or templates.

campaign-opened-AIM.doc: Retrieve the list of email addresses that opened a given campaign with how many times they opened.

list-webhook-del.doc: Delete an existing Webhook URL from a given list.

campaign-stats.doc: Given a list and a campaign, get all the relevant campaign statistics (opens, bounces, clicks, etc.)

campaign-delete.doc: Delete a campaign. Seriously, "poof, gone!" - be careful!.

ecomm-orders.doc: Retrieve the Ecommerce Orders for an account.

list-batch-unsubscribe.doc: Unsubscribe a batch of email addresses to a list.

list-interest-grouping-add.doc: Add a new Interest Grouping - if interest groups for the List are not yet enabled, adding the first grouping will automatically turn them on.

campaign-pause.doc: Pause an AutoResponder or RSS campaign from sending.

campaign-update.doc: Update just about any setting for a campaign that has not been sent. See campaigncreate() for details. campaign-advice.doc: Retrieve the text presented in our app for how a campaign performed and any advice we may have for you - best suited for display in customized reports pages. Note: some messages will contain HTML - clean tags as necessary.

templates.doc: Retrieve various templates available in the system, allowing some thing similar to our template gallery to be created. boolean user Customer template for this user account. template-info.doc: Pull details for a specific template to help support editing.

list-interest-group-del.doc: Delete a single Interest Group - if the last group for a list is deleted, this will also turn groups for the list off.

campaign-send-test.doc: Send a test of this campaign to the provided email address.

lists.doc: Retrieve all of the lists defined for your user account.

campaign-email-stats-AIM.doc: Given a campaign and email address, return the entire click and open history with timestamps, ordered by time.

campaigns-for-email.doc: Retrieve all Campaigns Ids a member was sent.

list-merge-var-add.doc: Add a new merge tag to a given list.

campaign-segment-test.doc: Allows one to test their segmentation rules before creating a campaign using them.

ping.doc: "Ping" the MailChimp API - a simple method you can call that will return a constant value as long as everything is good. campaign-click-stats.doc: Get an array of the urls being tracked, and their click counts for a given campaign.

folder-update.doc: Update the name of a folder for campaigns or autoresponders.

list-interest-grouping-del.doc: Delete an existing Interest Grouping - this will permanently delete all contained interest groups and will remove those selections from all list members.

campaign-members.doc: Get all email addresses the campaign was successfully sent to (ie, no bounces).

list-static-segment-members-add.doc: Add list members to a static segment. It is suggested that you limit batch size to no more than 10,000 addresses per call. Email addresses must exist on the list in order to be included - this will not subscribe them to the list!.

campaign-send-now.doc: Send a given campaign immediately. For RSS campaigns, this will "start" them.

list-subscribe.doc: Subscribe the provided email to a list.

lists-for-email.doc: Retrieve all List Ids a member is subscribed to.

apikey-expire.doc: Expire a Specific API Key. Note that if you expire all of your keys, just visit your API dashboard to create a new one. campaign-soft-bounces.doc: DEPRECATED Get all email addresses with Soft Bounces for a given campaign the email address that bounced.

chimp-chatter.doc: Return the current Chimp Chatter messages for an account.

list-webhooks.doc: Return the Webhooks configured for the given list.

list-member-info.doc: Get all the information for particular members of a list.

geocode-from-address.doc: Placename to geospatial coordinates converter, acting as a wrapper over the Yahoo! geocoder service.

currency-convert.doc: Currency conversion function, acting as a wrapper over the WebService from the European Central Bank. WebService documentation at http://www.ecb.int/stats/exchange/eurofxref/html/index.en.html

address-from-domain.doc: Uses a whois service to discover information about a given domain name, returning a sequence of strings for the addresses associated to the name.

address-from-geocode.doc: Geospatial coordinates to placename converter, acting as a wrapper over the Yahoo! reverse geocoder service.

address-from-phone.doc: Uses a White-pages Web service to discover information about a given phone number, returning a string for the address associated to the phone number.

phone-from-domain.doc: Uses a whois service to discover information about a given domain name, returning a sequence of strings for the phone numbers associated to the name.

name-from-domain.doc: Uses a whois service to discover information about a given domain name, returning a sequence of strings for the person or organization names associated to the name.

unit-convert.doc: Conversion function for units of measurement, acting as a wrapper over the CuppaIT WebService.

The logic contained in this module is not specific to any particular XQuery implementation, although the module requir...

Example usage : monge-elkan-jaro-winkler("Comput. Sci. and Eng. Dept., University of California, San Diego", "Department of Computer Scinece, Univ. Calif., San D...

The tokens from each string are weighted according to their occurence frequency (i.e., weighted according to the term-frequency heuristic from Information Retrieval). The tokens from each string are weighted according to their occurence frequency (i.e., weighted according to the term-frequency heuristic from Information Retrieval). The Metaphone phonetic similarity functi...

http://www.zorba-xquery.com/modules/data.doc: This library module provides data normalization functions for processing calendar dates, temporal values, currency values, units of measurement, location names and postal addresses. These functions are particularly useful for converting different data representations into cannonical formats. The log...

month-dictionary.doc: Internal auxiliary function that returns an XML representation for a dictionary that contains a numeric value associated to different month name abbreviations.

normalize-phone.doc: Uses an phone number normalization Web service to convert a phone number given as input into a cannonical representation.

to-dateTime.doc: Converts a given string representation of a dateTime value into a dateTime representation valid according to the corresponding XML Schema type.

normalize-address.doc: Uses an address normalization Web service to convert a postal address given as input into a cannonical representation format.

check-time.doc: Internal auxiliary function that checks if a string is in xs:time format

timeZone-dictionary.doc: Internal auxiliary function that returns an XML representation for a dictionary that contains the time-shift value associated to different time-zone abbreviations.

to-time.doc: Converts a given string representation of a time value into a time representation valid according to the corresponding XML Schema type.

check-dateTime.doc: Internal auxiliary function that checks if a string is in xs:dateTime format

check-date.doc: Internal auxiliary function that checks if a string is in xs:date format

to-date.doc: Converts a given string representation of a date value into a date representation valid according to the corresponding XML Schema type.

http://www.zorba-xquery.com/modules/data.doc: This library module provides phonetic string similarity functions, comparing strings with basis on how they sound. These metrics are particularly effective in matching names, since names are often spelled in different ways that sound the same. The logic contained in this module is not specific to an...

metaphone-key.doc: Returns the Metaphone key for a given string. The Metaphone algorithm produces variable length keys as its output, as opposed to Soundex's fixed-length keys. Example usage : metaphone-key("ALEKSANDER") The function invocation in the example above returns : "ALKSNTR"

soundex-key.doc: Returns the Soundex key for a given string. Example usage : soundex-key("Robert") The function invocation in the example above returns : "R163"

soundex.doc: Checks if two strings have the same Soundex key. Example usage : soundex( "Robert" , "Rupert" ) The function invocation in the example above returns : true

metaphone.doc: Checks if two strings have the same Metaphone key. Example usage : metaphone("ALEKSANDER", "ALEXANDRE") The function invocation in the example above returns : true

http://www.zorba-xquery.com/modules/data.doc: This library module provides similarity functions for comparing sets of XML nodes (e.g., sets of XML elements, attributes or atomic values). These functions are particularly useful for matching near duplicate sets of XML nodes. The logic contained in this module is not specific to any particular XQu...

deep-intersect.doc: Returns the intersection between two sets, using the deep-equal() function to compare the XML nodes from the sets. Example usage : deep-intersect ( ( "a", "b", "c") , ( "a", "a", ) ) The function invocation in the example above returns : ("a")

distinct.doc: Removes exact duplicates from a set, using the deep-equal() function to compare the XML nodes from the sets. Example usage : distinct ( ( "a", "a", ) ) The function invocation in the example above returns : ("a", )

deep-union.doc: Returns the union between two sets, using the deep-equal() function to compare the XML nodes from the sets. Example usage : deep-union ( ( "a", "b", "c") , ( "a", "a", ) ) The function invocation in the example above returns : ("a", "b", "c", )

dice.doc: Returns the Dice similarity coefficient between two sets of XML nodes. The Dice coefficient is defined as defined as twice the shared information between the input sets (i.e., the size of the intersection) over the sum of the cardinalities for the input sets. Example usage : dice ( ( "a", "b", ) , (...

jaccard.doc: Returns the Jaccard similarity coefficient between two sets of XML nodes. The Jaccard coefficient is defined as the size of the intersection divided by the size of the union of the input sets. Example usage : jaccard ( ( "a", "b", ) , ( "a", "a", "d") ) The function invocation in the example above r...

overlap.doc: Returns the overlap coefficient between two sets of XML nodes. The overlap coefficient is defined as the shared information between the input sets (i.e., the size of the intersection) over the size of the smallest input set. Example usage : overlap ( ( "a", "b", ) , ( "a", "a", "b" ) ) The function ...

http://www.zorba-xquery.com/modules/data.doc: This library module provides token-based string similarity functions that view strings as sets or multi-sets of tokens and use set-related properties to compute similarity scores. The tokens correspond to groups of characters extracted from the strings being compared, such as individual words or cha...

ngrams.doc: Returns the individual character n-grams forming a string. Example usage : ngrams("FLWOR", 2 ) The function invocation in the example above returns : ("_F" , "FL" , "LW" , "WO" , "LW" , "WO" , "OR" , "R_")

jaccard-tokens.doc: Returns the Jaccard similarity coefficient between sets of tokens extracted from two strings. Example usage : jaccard-tokens("The FLWOR Foundation", "FLWOR Found.", " +" ) The function invocation in the example above returns : 0.25

cosine-tokens.doc: Returns the cosine similarity coefficient between sets of tokens extracted from two strings. The tokens from each string are weighted according to their occurence frequency (i.e., weighted according to the term-frequency heuristic from Information Retrieval). Example usage : cosine-tokens("The FLWOR...

dice-ngrams.doc: Returns the Dice similarity coefficient between sets of character n-grams extracted from two strings. Example usage : dice-ngrams("DWAYNE", "DUANE", 2 ) The function invocation in the example above returns : 0.4615384615384616

overlap-ngrams.doc: Returns the overlap similarity coefficient between sets of character n-grams extracted from two strings. Example usage : overlap-ngrams("DWAYNE", "DUANE", 2 ) The function invocation in the example above returns : 0.5

jaccard-ngrams.doc: Returns the Jaccard similarity coefficient between sets of character n-grams extracted from two strings. Example usage : jaccard-ngrams("DWAYNE", "DUANE", 2 ) The function invocation in the example above returns : 0.3

cosine-ngrams.doc: Returns the cosine similarity coefficient between sets of character n-grams extracted from two strings. The n-grams from each string are weighted according to their occurence frequency (i.e., weighted according to the term-frequency heuristic from Information Retrieval). Example usage : cosine-ngram...

dice-tokens.doc: Returns the Dice similarity coefficient between sets of tokens extracted from two strings. Example usage : dice-tokens("The FLWOR Foundation", "FLWOR Found.", " +" ) The function invocation in the example above returns : 0.4

overlap-tokens.doc: Returns the overlap similarity coefficient between sets of tokens extracted from two strings. Example usage : overlap-tokens("The FLWOR Foundation", "FLWOR Found.", " +" ) The function invocation in the example above returns : 0.5

cosine.doc: Auxiliary function for computing the cosine similarity coefficient between strings, using stringdescriptors based on sets of character n-grams or sets of tokens extracted from two strings. Example usage : cosine( ("aa","bb") , ("bb","aa")) The function invocation in the example above returns : 1.0

http://www.zorba-xquery.com/modules/date.doc: This module provides functions to retrieve the current dateTime. In contrast to the current-dateTime functions specified in "XQuery Functions and Operators" the functions in this module are nondeterministic. That is, they do not return the current-dateTime from the dynamic context but return the act...

current-date.doc: Return the current date value. Please note, that this function is not stable. It returns the dat value of the date the function has been actually invoked.

timestamp.doc: Return the the number of milliseconds since the Epoch.

current-dateTime.doc: Return the current dateTime value. Please note, that this function is not stable. It returns the dateTime value of the date and time the function has actually been invoked.

current-time.doc: Return the current time value. Please note, that this function is not stable. It returns the time value of the date and time the function has actually been invoked.

process.doc: Process one message received from the Zorba debugger server.

http://www.zorba-xquery.com/modules/emai.doc: This module provides functions for accessing and manipulating emails on mail servers through the IMAP protocol. All functions in this module receive as the first argument the IMAP host and user information. This is an element with the type hostInfoType as defined in the email schema: http://www.zorb...

unsubscribe.doc: Unsubscribes the user from the specified mailbox.

copy.doc: Copies messages between mailboxes. Depending on the value of $uid , the messages are either specified through their sequence number or through their unique id. Both mailboxes must exist.

delete.doc: Deletes a mailbox for the given user.

move.doc: Moves messages between mailboxes. Depending on the value of $uid , the messages are either specified through their sequence number or through their unique id. Both mailboxes must exist.

fetch-uid.doc: Fetches the unique identifier for a given message sequence number.

fetch-message-sequence-number.doc: Fetches the message sequence number for a given unique identifier.

status.doc: Returns the status of the given mailbox. The status of a mailbox contains: messages : the number of messages in the mailbox recent : the number of messages flagged as recent unseen : the number of messages flagged as unseen uidnext : the next unique identifier that will be assigned to a message uidv...

set-flags.doc: Sets the flags for a given message. The flags are set and unset according to the passed $flags .

list.doc: Lists IMAP folders for the specified user on the host that match the pattern.

create.doc: Creates a new mailbox for the given user.

fetch-from.doc: Fetches the 'from' string of a message. Please note that this function only words with message sequence numbers, not with unique identifiers. Only the first 255 characters of a 'from' string are fetched.

search.doc: Searches a mailbox for messages that match the given criteria. The criteria should be a string as defined in the RFC3501 (IMAP4rev1). A valid example would be: 'FROM zorba@gmail.com OR NOT SUBJECT Bug'. Depending on the value of $uid , the function will either return matching sequence numbers or uni...

expunge.doc: Permanently deletes all messages of the given mailbox that have the "deleted" flag set.

fetch-subject.doc: Fetches the subject for a message. Please note that this function only works with message sequence numbers, not with unique identifiers. Only the first 255 characters of a subject are fetched.

subscribe.doc: Subscribes the user to the specified mailbox.

http://www.zorba-xquery.com/modules/emai.doc: This module can be used for sending emails. The SMTP module contains only one public function that receives two parameters. The SMTP server access information passed as an hostInfo element and the email message representation as a message element. For a quick start see the examples associates with t...

send.doc: This function sends an email message from the specified account. The hostName child element of $host-info must have the form: remote_system_name [":" port ] [ flags ] . This syntax is part of the Remote names syntax defined in the UW IMAP toolkit. The remote_system_name and flags fragments are expla...

http://www.zorba-xquery.com/modules/exce.doc: This is a library module offering the same set of functions defined by Microsoft Excel.

is-leap-year.doc: Tests if a year is leap or not.

weekday.doc: Returns the day of the week corresponding to a $date.
Returns the day of the week corresponding to a $date depending on $return_type.

time.doc: Constructs a time given the hours, minutes and seconds.

networkdays.doc: Returns the number of whole working days between $start_date and $end_date.
Returns the number of whole working days between $start_date and $end_date.

minute.doc: Returns the minutes of a time value.

day.doc: Returns the day of a $date, represented by a serial number.

date.doc: Constructs a date given the hours, months and days.

days360.doc: Returns the number of days between two dates based on a 360-day year.
Returns the number of days between two dates based on a 360-day year.

day-of-week.doc: The day of the week, from a date.

hour.doc: Returns the hour of a time value.

year.doc: Returns the year corresponding to a date.

http://www.zorba-xquery.com/modules/exce.doc: This is a library module offering the same set of functions defined by Microsoft Excel, under Engineering Functions.

bin2decUtil.doc: Returns a decimal representation of a number given it's binary representation.

dec2hexUtil.doc: Returns a binary representation of a number.

is-bin.doc: Tests if a string is a binary representation of a number.

hex2decUtil.doc: Returns a decimal representation of a number given it's hexadecimal representation.

dec2binUtil.doc: Returns a binary representation of a number.

is-hex.doc: Tests if a string is a hexadecimal representation of a number.

dec2octUtil.doc: Returns an octal representation of a number.

is-oct.doc: Tests if a string is a octal representation of a number.

oct2decUtil.doc: Returns a decimal representation of a number given it's octal representation.

http://www.zorba-xquery.com/modules/exce.doc: This is a library module offering the same set of functions defined by Microsoft Excel, under Information Functions.

isnumber.doc: Tests if the passed $value is a number.

islogical.doc: Tests if the passed $value is a logical value.

istext.doc: Tests if the passed $value is a string.

is-blank.doc: Test if the passed argument is empty of not.

http://www.zorba-xquery.com/modules/exce.doc: This is a library module offering the same set of functions defined by Microsoft Excel, under Logical Functions.

if.doc: Returns one value if a condition you specify evaluates to TRUE and another value if it evaluates to FALSE.

or.doc: Returns TRUE if any argument is TRUE; FALSE if all arguments are FALSE.
Returns TRUE if any argument is TRUE; FALSE if all arguments are FALSE.

and.doc: Returns TRUE if all its arguments are TRUE; FALSE if one or more arguments are FALSE.
Returns TRUE if all its arguments are TRUE; FALSE if one or more arguments are FALSE.

http://www.zorba-xquery.com/modules/exce.doc: This module implements some Excel 2003 lookup functions.

hlookup.doc: Same as above, only that range_lookup is defaulted to true. That is, this Hlookup looks for the approximate value and the first row must be ordered ascending.

Searches for a value in the top row of an array of values, and then returns a value in the same column from a row you specify in the array. Array is specified with 3 parameters: table_array is a sequence of elements, first row first, then second row and so on table_width specifies the number of elem...

choose.doc: Uses index_num to return a sequence from the list of sequences. Use CHOOSE to select one of up to 29 sequences based on the index number.
Uses index_num to return a value from the sequence of value arguments.

lookup.doc: The Vector form. Looks in a sequence for a value and return a value from the same position in a second sequence. If the value is not found, then it matches the largest value in lookup_vector that is less than or equal to lookup_value.

The Array form. It looks in the first row or column of an array for the specified value and returns a value from the same position in the last row or column of the array. If array covers an area that is wider than it is tall (more columns than rows), LOOKUP searches for lookup_value in the first row...

transpose.doc: Transposes an array. The rows become columns and vice versa.

index.doc: Returns a value from within an array. This is the Array form of the Excel Index function. Array is specified with 3 parameters: array is a sequence of elements, first row first, then second row and so on array_height specifies the number of rows array_width specifies the number of elements in a row ...

lookup-column.doc: Function for HLOOKUP, LOOKUP, MATCH, VLOOKUP. This function should not be used outside this module. It searches a lookup_value in table_header with three different algorithms specified by range_lookup.

match.doc: Same as above, but match_type is defaulted to 1. It finds the largest value that is less than or equal to lookup_value.
Returns the relative position of an item in a sequence that matches a specified value in a specified order. Only for one dimensional vector.

vlookup.doc: Same as above, with range_lookup defaulted to true. It finds the largest value that is less than or equal to lookup_value. First column must be in ascending order.

Searches for a value in the first column of a table array and returns a value in the same row from another column in the table array. Array is specified with 3 parameters: table_array is a sequence of elements, first row first, then second row and so on table_width specifies the number of elements i...

offset.doc: Same as above, only that the sub-array is specified only by rows and cols relative position. The sub-array height and width is computed to contain the remaining elements of the array.
Returns a sub-array from an array. The inner array must be within the reference array
